reviewText: I love movies directed by Clint Eastwood, he's a great story teller and his somewhat unhurried shooting style never fails to draw me in, even `Hereafter' which I thought was a bit bland, was beautifully shot. Here, Eastwood delivers again in `J.Edgar', a biopic that follows the career of the man who created what is now known as the Federal Bureau of Investigations; J. Edgar Hoover.I can't speak for the accuracy of the history or how they portrayed the man, I'm sure some things were embellished for the sake of drama, but as a film, Eastwood has crafted a compelling and engaging movie. I was fascinated at seeing how the FBI started out as a powerless bureau and Hoover crafted it into the law enforcement organization it is today, not to mention make headway into forensics investigations.Watching Hoover himself, and his complicated relationships with the people around him, was an emotional rollercoaster as things unfolded on screen, I found myself rooting for J. Edgar one minute and absolutely hating him the next to pitying him later on, and sometimes all at the same time as well. If you're looking for anything about Hoover's cross-dressing, you'll be sorely disappointed, it is only briefly touched on here, but the bulk of the movie is about the FBI.Leonardo DiCaprio is captivating as the very much flawed titular character and Armie Hammer is equally strong as Hoover's right-hand man, Clyde Tolson. Naomi Watts doesn't let the film down either as Hoover's personal assistant and Judi Dench as Hoover's mother. But, really, all the actors go a tremendous job at getting us into these characters.`J. Edgar' is worth a watch if not the purchase, if there was one thing that bothered me about the movie it's that it does jump back and forth a lot between time periods, it's like one moment you're in the 1920's the next, it's the 1960's, it can be a bit confusing in some parts, other than that, this is a great movie manages to keep you engaged for it's 137 minute run-time.The disc includes `J. Edgar: a complicated man', it's a short documentary with the cast and crew talking about Hoover and also shooting the film. It's okay, but nothing special.

reviewText: "J. Edgar" was a well acted historical piece attempting to cover a complicated subject that, when all was said and done, left me feeling it was less than the sum of its parts.  To put it more simply, it was everything I thought it would be...but I wish it would have been just a little bit less.Starring Leonardo DiCaprio as the titular figurehead, "J. Edgar" intrigued me from the start.  Certainly the film would discuss the birth of the FBI, and J. Edgar Hoover's fanatical protection and promotion of that institution, of his pioneering a national fingerprint system, and his hatred of communism.  Would it also tackle his secret files full of blackmail material on political enemies, and his supposed homosexuality and cross-dressing?And the answer is YES to all those things...and that's almost a shame.  There is SO much information here that the film tends to be exhaustive AND exhausting at the same time.  Eastwood has always been a meticulous director, nurturing his characters and his subjects, and perhaps he might have been wise to be a little less so, to have cut a bit more here and there.  The film is almost two hours and twenty minutes, and I was actually pleased to see the feller die...I was that tired.Eastwood's screenplay was written by Dustin Lance Black ("Milk"), and their decision to tell their tale in a dual present/past fashion through cuts and flashbacks will probably draw some criticism, and may have been partly responsible for my feeling that the story went on a little too long.  Cutting between the two tales was a bit jarring at times, and often frustrated me more than drew me in.Whether DiCaprio will be honored by any acting nominations will remain to be seen.  I felt he was good, though a little uncharacteristically wooden.  While he covered the man from 1919 to 1972, and did a decent job showing the man aging, I think as much credit should go to the makeup department as it should to him.  For instance, I did not feel his voice aged anywhere near as much as his body did, and it bothered me.On the other hand, there are three supporting characters who I thought were remarkable.  The first and second were Armie Hammer as Clyde Tolson, Hoover's confidante and (apparently) all-but-sexual partner; and Naomi Watts as Helen Gandy, his extremely loyal and supportive secretary.  I found them to be credible and well played, especially Hammer as his meticulous, caring, loving friend.  Whether their relationship was indeed one of only implied sexuality I am not sure, but both Eastwood's coy directing and Hammer's capable acting give few specifics as to how far their relationship indeed went.And I have saved the best for last: Judy Dench is pure magic as Hoover's domineering mother, a thoroughly unlikable woman who created a stunted man maniacally driven to please her, though he almost never can.  I would be extremely surprised if the Dame does not win an acting award for this role.There is a telling scene near the start where J. Edgar, who is using his full first name (John) at the time, is buying his very first tailored suit as the newly established head of the FBI, and he is told that another John Hoover is a credit risk...would there be some way he could distinguish himself?  Whether this scene is fully factual or not it works, and the notion of entitling the film as such serves to establish just who Hoover was, the man who invented himself AND the FBI.
summary: J. Edgar": Well-Acted, Complex, Serious, and a Little Too Long

reviewText: From the moment I heard that Clint Eastwood was working on this film I became eager for the release. I was particularly eager to see how Leonardo Dicaprio would handle both the role, and Eastwood's direction. Hoover the man was a controversial character full of personal peccadillos both documented and heavily speculated upon. With such a vast amount of conflicting information available, I was deeply intrigued to see the manner in which the data would be presented. His paranoia was legendary, as were his interactions and fundamental mistrust of several of the presidents under which he served.I didn't read much in the way of reviews either here at Amazon or in the media prior to viewing the film - I even eschewed watching the trailer - because I wanted to meet the film at "face value" as I had many of Eastwood's other directorial efforts. My opinions of the movie are therefore my own, and not based on the praise and/or criticisms of others that have viewed the movie.On the plus side, Eastwood doesn't sensationalize the allegations of homosexuality and cross dressing that would have made Hoover an easy target for exploitation. Such matters are presented in a manner that manages to make their possibilities a very realistic conclusion to be drawn, but doesn't accept them as fact. The one kiss that takes place with Hoover's longtime "partner" is rejected by J Edgar who demands that such a thing never be done again. Unlike "Milk" in which the viewer is constantly bombarded with the protagonist's sexuality, in J. Edgar the sexual inclinations are present as a part of the man, but not the driving focus of his life.It is a delicate balance, but largely handled in a deft manner in the film.On the negative side of the ledger however, is the overall bleak nature of the production. The colors are a dull pallette of greys and drab hues, which leaves the eye little stimulation to help with the slow pacing of the story. Eastwood also jumps back and forth frequently, choosing to relate the story in more flashbacks than necessary instead of presenting Hoover's life in a linear manner. As a result of these two filmaking decisions, the viewer almost has to work too hard to maintain interest and keep track of the flow of the narrative.For people who lived through the Hoover years, or have taken even a cursory glance at the man's Wiki bio, there are few surprises here. In fact, to the movie's detriment, it is likely that many viewers will already know more about the man than is presented. I have enjoyed virtually all of Eastwood's prior directorial efforts, but this one was just too slow and dry for my taste. I was also pulled out of the film several times by the makeup. I'm not usually bothered by such things, but at times the methods used to artificially age the main characters was so caky-looking I kept expecting to see chunks of it break off.Overall, this is a very average biopic, but a surprisingly poor film when compared to the past efforts of almost all those involved in the project both in front of, and behind the camera. It represents a rare but fairly large weakness in Eastwood's almost perfect directorial resume.

reviewText: I will have to disagree with the many one-star reviewers who say this movie delves too much into Hoover's private sexual lives.  It does not.  What it does seem to emphasize is how weird he was, how a momma's boy who never married had an obsession with everyone else's sexual orientation because he himself was confused of his own.This movie shows the personal side of Hoover.  The movie spares any naked scenes between J Edgar Hoover and his long-time confidante Clyde Tolson; the closest is reveals is a fight scene at 1:34 hours and a few hand-holding seconds. For the remainder of the movie the focus is on Hoover's quirky obsessions with Martin Luther King Jr, the Kennedys, and the personal relationship between Hoover and Tolson that seemed to crumble in its later years.  It also shows how Hoover often falsified or exaggerated reports to make him seem like the nation's perfect crime fighter when in fact others did that job for him.The acting is fine by all the starring casts.  DiCaprio does an outstanding job and so does Naomi Watts as his personal secretary Helen Gandy.  Armie Hammer rounds out the main characters as Clyde Tolson.What I did find distracting is the director's constant going back and forth between the young and the old Hoover.  Director Clint Eastwood also seems to have a preference of using side lighting that makes the other half of a person's face disappear into deep shadows, something he also used in "Million Dollar Baby," with piano music accompanying the somber scenes.The movie flows at times as if Hoover is dictating his life to his personally-appointed biographer.  The make-up on "Tolson" also makes him look like a corpse, whereas Hoover himself is aged well.There is emphasis on the botched Lindbergh kidnapping case, obsession with the Roosevelts (both Franklin and Eleanor) and later MLK.  Not enough was devoted to Hoover's dealings with the mafia of the 1930s, and nothing is mentioned about the FBI files of Vietnam War protesters.So, watch this with the above caveats.  This movie shows more of the personal side of Hoover and touches only on the many bizarre and above-the-law tactics Hoover employed to gather information on anyone he seemed treasonous against America.  Presidents both feared and admired him, and that is evident in the alleged quote Nixon said upon learning of Hoover's death, a quote I can't post here because Amazon will refuse to post my review.

reviewText: I can't recall knowing much of anything about J. Edgar Hoover before seeing this film. Other than recognizing the name, everything else was pretty much a mystery. I suppose that's why it was so intriguing; controversy is always interesting. Here is this man that became known for his incredibly strict standards, his loyalty to his work, his rise to the top of law enforcement, and basically helped the way crimes are solved and prosecuted evolve to what we're familiar with today who basically had confidential files on every major player he'd ever been in contact with, was completely clueless when it came to the opposite sex, and may or may not have been homosexual.The film begins during the Palmer Raids of late 1919 and early 1920 and covers everything up to Hoover's death in 1972. We constantly jump back in forth in time as an older J. Edgar (Leonardo DiCaprio) is narrating his version of his life and the younger version of J. Edgar in the 30s as he rose to the top of the Bureau of Investigation and formed the FBI. The way the film transitions between the early 1930s and 1972 and the way these transitions are edited is part of the film's charm. It already has this kind of filter on it; the one that seems to have become associated with most of Clint Eastwood's directorial efforts. Everything looks kind of semi-drained of its color and is kind of hazy. It looks the way you'd imagine the past if somebody was telling you a story and they cued a flashback or something.The unfortunate thing is the film has something really intriguing at its core, but it's presented so blandly. There's a huge explosion early on in the film, gangsters, gunfire, and a dead body among other things but it's all spread out amongst rather underwhelming dialogue. DiCaprio becomes incredibly emotional in the final half hour or so, but he seems to be holding back the rest of the time. Other than portraying a different accent, he seems to just be going with the flow while the same can be said for Naomi Watts. While DiCaprio does pull it together later on, Armie Hammer practically acts circles around him the entire time. His facial expressions are what give away just how much he enjoys being in the company of J. Edgar and his portrayal of an older man with health problems is practically spot-on. Judi Dench also has quite a few memorable scenes as J. Edgar's mother Anna Marie. Keep a particular eye out for the "Daffy" conversation between her and J. Edgar.The make-up effects are easily a shoe-in to win an Oscar this year. Not only are they fantastic, but trying to think of worthy competition is almost impossible. X-Men: First Class perhaps? Either way they did a phenomenal job here. The subtle sex jokes became increasingly awkward as the film progressed. However, that was more than likely its purpose. There is also one of the most oafish kiss scenes in cinematic history included in here. While watching J. Edgar, I couldn't help but think of David Fincher's Zodiac. It was mostly in the way both films seemed to ease you into conversations and reactions revolving around what interested you in the film to begin with rather than throwing you headfirst into the subject (The Zodiac Killer and J. Edgar's private life respectively). The flaw with that comparison is that Zodiac is still more interesting than J. Edgar.J. Edgar comes off as longwinded and fairly boring the majority of the time. There is a fascinating story buried within its roots, but somewhere between pen and paper and the big screen a bland representation of what it once was became the movie we know today. Leonardo DiCaprio almost seems to hold back most of the film while Armie Hammer manages to outshine him at every turn and shows how ridiculously talented he really is. J. Edgar isn't downright awful, but it isn't great either. Even though they only played a minor role, J. Edgar manages to be the lamest and dullest film featuring gangsters I've ever seen.

reviewText: Let's face it: J. Edgar Hoover is one of the more controversial figures of the 20th Century.  He was the top lawman in the nation, but he often resorted to unsavory tactics to bring down the bad guys (and kept files on a bunch of the "good" guys whose views he distrusted, such as JFK and Martin Luther King, Jr.).  He was a complex human being: hero and villain at the same time, insecure but powerful, distrusting even of his own emotions.  No one film could ever capture such a figure.J. EDGAR tries.  It really does.  Dustin Lance Black's (MILK) script is solid, if not quite eventful.  Despite such a volatile central figure, the closest thing to a climactic moment comes between Hoover and his rumored lover, Clyde Tolson; that would be great, if this were a film about Hoover's possible homosexuality, but it isn't.  Nor is it a film about Hoover's political subterfuge.  Or the founding of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.  It's a film about all of that, which means it ends up, really, being a film about none of it.  It tries encompassing too much, and in the end, it's as though everyone involved unanimously agreed that Hoover was far too complex for that.  So they settled for something a little watered-down.That's not to say this film doesn't have its merits.  It's another solid piece of filmmaking from director Clint Eastwood.  It's not in his "great" category (say, UNFORGIVEN or MYSTIC RIVER); it's more like INVICTUS, which was undeniably good but otherwise unremarkable.  Likewise, Leonardo DiCaprio gives a layered performance at the titular character; it's not his best, either, but it's worth watching.  The best moments of the film come from the inferiority Hoover feels from interacting with others, namely Judi Dench as his mother, Armie Hammer as Tolson, and Naomi Watts as trustworthy secretary Helen Gandy.  It is in these moments that J. EDGAR shows glimmers of what it could have been.  Unfortunately, each relationship could easily have been its own film, and that's not even brushing the various political angles.  As is, J. EDGAR is a film that tries to do too much--but at least you know you have a solid, dependable crew behind at the helm.
summary: Well-acted and well-made, but never as gripping as it should be.

reviewText: Clint Eastwood's latest masterpiece covers the highs and lows of J Edgar Hoover's rise to power. Clint has been on a serious roll for several years now. And we can add this film towards the top of his directing resume. There is so much ground to cover in J Edgar's life and career its impossible to cover everything. This is where many people feel this film came up short. Well for over 2 hours, Mr. Eastwood has crafted an entertaining look at a complex figure in our nations history. There are some areas that he chose not to explore too deeply - and that was probably a wise move.J Edgar's career is not the only focus in the film. His relationships with his mother as well as his number 2 man- Clyde Tolson are also part of the fabric of this film. He is so close to his mother and values her opinions that he lives with her for much of his younger years. And you can sense that when the time comes when he will be without his mother, it will be very difficult on Edgar. He also developes a very close relationship with his number 2 man. This relationship is put to the test in several scenes, as both men struggle with their feelings. Mr.Toloson, although questioned by Edgar about his loyalty is always there for Edgar. He loves Edgar very deeply and the feeling is mutual. But Mr.Tolson's feelings run a little deeper and exposes this more when Edgar mentions that he wants to marry a woman. Its one of the more powerful scenes in the movie.The film follows Edgar from his early investigations into communist radicals in the 1919/1920 era until the Nixon administration comes to Washington. In the early days Edgar has many new ideas that he has to put into place to make the bureau stronger and able to conduct the type of work that he feels is right to get the job done. There is opposition. His ideals and suggestions meet resistance. But in the end ideas like finger printing and crime lab work win out. When America cheers on the mobsters on the big screen, Edgar is trying to end their rein on the streets. In his mind he is making all the arrests and he adores the attention of cleaning the streets of thugs. But is this reality? The Lindberg kidnapping is covered very well here. Where the crime scene and evidence from the crime scene showcase Edgar's beliefs in solving cases. The cops appear to be sloppy and often overlook key pieces of evidience. The film follows Edgar through the Kennedy era and civil rights with Dr.King. There certainly wouldn't be enough time in a movie like this to explore everything. But the events are touched on with the right amount of attention for each moment in history.This is Leonardo Dicaprio's finest acting performance. I haven't seen every one of his films, but I have seen almost all of them. He plays this role so well and with conviction. I can think of no other actor that could have done a better job. This isn't just a role about a man in a particular time period. He has to play Edgar through several decades. And he pulls this off quite well. I was very impressed with him in this movie.  Armie Hammer is also excellent as Clyde Tolson. Another great performance that won't be forgotten. I felt like his performance was very strong as Mr.Tolson was in his declining years. He played the part of a frail man with a stroke very well. He had the mannerisms down for this type of decline. Naomi Watts does a nice job as Mr.Hoover's secretary. She devotes her life to the bureaus work and has to put up with Edgar's decisions in sometimes difficult circumstances. And like Mr.Tolson, Miss Gandy is reliable in every situation- especially the end. And the makeup for this film was great. They did a stellar job of creating these characters as they age through the years.I give this  4 1/2 stars. It would be great to have seen a little more, but most people wouldn't enjoy a movie much longer than this one. Edgar held secret files on presidents and other powerful figures- and for over 2 hours our minds were entertainedThe BLu Ray also comes with a nice little feature on J Edgar the man from those involved with the film. Eastwood, Dicaprio and several others comment on the different sides to J Edgar- good and bad. And what his place in history might have been if things were different. Definately worth checking out.

reviewText: I have to say that I enjoyed this film overall. J. Edgar Hoover is a difficult subject to approach as a film, he was a man liked by almost no one, and feared and loathed by many, which makes him difficult to use as a sympathetic character, and indeed most of the time he's not. J. Edgar Hoover was also a man very much caught up in his own myth, and the film does a good job of showing that. Leonardo DiCaprio does a very good job of bringing the character to life, though I suspect the real J. Edgar was an altogether stiffer and more opaque person. The director (wisely, probably) chose not to delve to deeply into Hoover's alleged homosexuality, choosing to portray him as a celibate closeted gay man, sharing a close friendship with another obviously gay man, but never "consummating" it. Given how little is really known of Hoover's private life, this was probably the prudent choice for this part of the film. The film does a very good job of capturing the style and look of the time accurately, the clothes, cars, interiors, lighting, it's all very authentic looking. We are removed enough from the Hoover era at this point where for most people he's a relatively enigmatic character at this point, far removed from the "G-man" hero he wanted to be remembered as, and also far removed from the fearsome trampler of rights and prolific spy and wiretapper who was so feared and reviled while he was in power. The scene with an overly youthful looking Nixon drew a few chuckles from me, some considered it over the top, but it looks like vintage Nixon to me. If you've read the transcripts of his tapes, his lines in the film ring true. The only thing that I found perplexing was the strange loyalty shown by those closest to him towards such an imperious and often mercurial boss, but perhaps that's just my take on it.

reviewText: As others have mentioned, "J. Edgar" is more of a character study than a straightforward biography or documentary, and there are times when "soap opera" might be a better term. The general picture it paints is one of an ultra-neurotic buffoon, albeit one with a few admirable qualities. Although Hoover may have been a hard guy to completely like or admire, it just seems the creators had some issues with their subject that show through a bit too obviously. Also, the way the film reverberates between public (Hoover's formation of the FBI, Communist subversives, kidnapping of the Lindbergh's baby, etc) and private life (his close relationship with his overbearing mother, awkwardness with most other women,workaholism,cross-dressing and apparent latent homosexuality, etc) gives it a patchy feeling. Granted, coverage of both areas is necessary, and they are not easy ones for a director to synthesize. Nevertheless, some bad choices were made here regarding what to include and what not to. There is nothing, for example, on the prosecution of the Rosenbergs or the FBI's role during the Vietnam War years. I, for one, would have liked to see more on such areas and less on Hoover's family life (or lack thereof) and his relationship with his right-hand man, Clyde Tolson.Despite the long time-span it covers, "J. Edgar" is smooth enough to follow, and Hoover's conflicting qualities--e.g., insistence on professional conduct and limitations of the Bureau's jurisdiction, yet, defiance of his own standards by becoming a sort of Rona Barrett of Washington--are often quite intriguing. Still, a linear biography told from a more distant and objective third person perspective might have worked better as the structure of this film.Most of the acting is tepid, but Judi Dench and Naomi Watts both give admirable performances as the two important women in Hoover's life (though I agree, the make-up is terrible).

reviewText: The magic of films and stage plays is that the audience suspends its belief system for two hours and pretends that it is observing reality. Yet part of the brain knows it is participating in make believe -- otherwise we would be psychotic. This suspension of disbelief is not automatic, however. The responsibility of the medium is to present its subject matter with as much realism as possible to assist the viewer's imagination. So a film that takes place in the 1930s will have old cars and old clothing, etc., to lend authenticity and facilitate the suspension of disbelief. The job of the actors is to perform their craft with such transparency that the audience can believe in the authenticity of the characters. Spencer Tracy, when asked for his definition of good acting, replied, "Never let them catch you doing it."My beef with J. Edgar is that Leonardo DiCaprio with globs of make-up does not J. Edgar Hoover make. And I wonder: Why do some of Hollywood's best directors make this same mistake? In The Aviator, superb director Martin Scorsese asked my imagination to accept this same Leonardo as Howard Hughes. I have enjoyed DiCaprio in a number of lighter roles (e.g., he was fine in Titanic) but as Hughes? Not a chance. Incredible miscasting, Mr. Scorsese, shame on you. And shame on Clint Eastwood, who has turned in so many wonderful films, for slinging a ton of make-up on this boyish actor and asking him to inhabit the skin of a character who is as un-boyish as you can get, namely Hoover. The result is a film that lacks a credible center.Instead of portraying Mr. Hoover as the monster that he was, J. Edgar is a film about a momma's boy who is a paranoid clown. Eastwood attempts to dramatize important events in the history of the FBI and what he delivers is light comedy. A good example is Eastwood's treatment of the homosexual relationship between Hoover and his aide, Clyde Tolson: The two men are alone in a hotel suite. Hoover admits having had an affair with Dorothy Lamour (the thought of which is hilarious in its own right) and he and Tolson wind up on the floor in a mock fight that is reminiscent of the Three Stooges. Another example is Hoover's penchant for firing anyone who tries to upstage him, which becomes nothing more than a silly motif. In another scene, Eleanor Roosevelt is exposed for having an affair with a woman. This kind of intrusion into the private lives of individuals, an example of Hoover's vindictiveness, made me laugh instead of feeling disgust for Hoover.Much of the film is delivered in flash-back. Unfortunately Mr. DiCaprio's acting as a young Hoover is the same as his acting as an older Hoover with the exception of the make-up. His side-kick Tolson fares even worse in this regard. His make-up is a left-over from a Mummy film. At one point, Tolson faints and Hoover shouts, "Get a doctor!" I turned to the person sitting next to me and said, "Get a make-up artist!" In terms of Hoover's character and what made him tick, I learned nothing from this screenplay except for a few broad strokes, e.g., Hoover's obsession with his mother. The intense, dangerous bulldog that I think of when I conjure up a portrait of J. Edgar Hoover was nowhere to be found.On top of all this, the pacing of the film is geriatric. My friend kept falling asleep and I had to nudge her several times. The one aspect that kept me awake was the story of the Lindbergh kidnapping, which should have been the subject of the film rather than this shallow look at a complex public figure.
summary: Hoover as quaint clown doesn't cut it

reviewText: J. EDGAR (dir. Clint Eastwood, 2011, 126 mins.) is one of the highlights of film - and one of the finest 'biopics' ever crafted. It is always my pleasure and honor to be able to say, after watching an Eastwood film, that it is among the finest I've ever seen. This film is no exception.The movie is precisely a biopic of the FBI director (and essentially its founder), really no more and no less. Do not let anyone tell you a pitch-perfect biography is easy for a director to do. In recent films, the couple of pathetic appearances by lousy bit-players in the role of Hoover only added to the need for this film.Done partly from flashbacks and partly from an elderly Hoover's own narration - as he dictates his memoires about finding and arresting Baby Lindbergh's kidnapper - the film deftly flashes backward and forward in time, leading us from the start of his dictation, flashing back to his start as director of the Bureau of Investigation.It continues in this way, back-and-forth, showing every detail as most Hoover students know it. Nothing is over-the-top, as Eastwood is a man of subtleties. Even Deputy Director Clyde Tolson (the gorgeous Armie Hammer), who was as close to a spouse as Hoover ever had, is beautifully and quietly portrayed. Dame Judi Dench as Hoover's mother is sparkling and convincing. Every actor in this film is breathtaking - whether shown only for seconds, such as Manu Intiraymi (STAR TREK VOYAGER) as the infamous Alvin Karpis, or shown constantly like the eternal presence of Hoover's faithful secretary Helen Gandy (Naomi Watts).Leo DiCaprio is no slouch here. While the makeup is Oscar-worthy and I can't imagine Oscar skipping over the achievement, it is DiCaprio at his finest. Perhaps above and beyond his finest. There is a mean, snotty, Jon Voigt-like quality in his aged Hoover; the youthful Hoover is just nervous and goofy enough to be believable to those of us who remember him when he was a younger man.I believe DiCaprio has an Oscar in the can for this; likewise Eastwood. Don't miss the chance to see this for the genuine skinny on a man who has been more reviled and hated than anyone since Hitler - it will inspire you to read the rest of the story and discover what this man Hoover really did for this country.No one can ask for a better film than this. However, a wonderful, lively companion piece that I think is a must-see is 1977'sThe Private Files Of J. Edgar Hoover (MGM Limited Edition Collection)(see my review), a star-studded and realistic extravaganza of great history, locations and top-notch acting.

reviewText: In the history of America during the 20th century, few people were as revered, admired, feared, and hated (sometimes all at once) as J. Edgar Hoover, the mercurial, often-paranoid man who ruled over the Federal Bureau of Investigation from 1924 until his death in 1972.  In his time, he saw the expunging of Communist subversives, the destruction of Depression-era gangsters like John Dillinger, and an ability to keep tabs and files on people in high places in the U.S. government, including all the presidents and attorneys general that he held sway over, not to mention even ordinary citizens whom he felt were disloyal to American values.  But there was that one personal secret of his that he definitely did not want getting out, which would have destroyed the image he had built up of himself as the toughest law enforcement chief there was.  All of Hoover's aspects, savory and unsavory alike, are shown in great detail by director Clint Eastwood in J. EDGAR, one of the great biopics of recent vintage.Told largely in flashbacks that span the first indications in 1919 of a Bolshevik revolution threatening America, to 1972, when Hoover died, J. EDGAR stars Leonardo DiCaprio in a mesmerizing performance as the tough-as-nails FBI man who prided himself of getting rid of the rotten elements in American society, and ordering his bureau and his agents to live up to his professional standards of loyalty and patriotism.  Both Eastwood and screenwriter Dustin Lance Black depict the great things Hoover's FBI did, but they don't whitewash the fact that he was also a shameless, unapologetic huckster and salesman at boosting the FBI image at home and abroad, sometimes even boosting his own image by taking credit for certain big FBI catches (capturing the killer of Charles Lindbergh's baby; the killing of Dillinger) that he was never even present at--and, of course, the fact that his relationship with his close aid Clyde Tolson (Armie Hammer) was, how shall we say, more than merely professional.  Eastwood, more content now to be behind the camera than in front of it, gets a great performance out of DiCaprio, as well as solid turns by Naomi Watts (as Hoover's long-time secretary Helen Gundy), Dame Judi Dench (as his mother Annie), and Jessica Hecht as the notorious subversive Emma Goldman, most of them unrecognizable, including DiCaprio, under all the prosthetics and make-up, but still able to deliver the goods.As a director, Eastwood proved long ago, going all the way back to his directing debut PLAY MISTY FOR ME in 1971, that he was more than just Dirty Harry or the Man With No Name, that he was a director of offbeat and extremely challenging projects, whether or not he was also on the other side of the camera as an actor.  Recent films of his like CHANGELING, LETTERS FROM IWO JIMA, INVICTUS, HEREAFTER, and MILLION DOLLAR BABY proved this; and J. EDGAR does as well.  This is a film to be appreciated, not only for its detail, but also for giving us an unvarnished glimpse into a man who, regardless of how one feels about him, changed the face of American law enforcement forever, sometimes for the best, and yet just as often for the worst.
summary: America's Top G Man--Warts (Lots Of Them) And All, Courtesy Of Eastwood

reviewText: J. EDGAR is a cinematic accomplishment of the first order! From the screenplay (Dustin Lance Black) as acted by a host of consummate actors and directed with extreme sensitivity by Clint Eastwood, the sum of the parts is an extraordinary achievement in presenting a portrait of one of the strangest men in history.  The manner in which the life and deeds and personality are woven together presents as full an image of a man of contradictions, a man who planned to have his personal files destroyed after his death in order to maintain the iconic image he so desperately desired, is nothing short of a work of dedicated investigation on parts of everyone involved.  And electing to tell this story through the ever-changing  chameleon aspects of this bizarre man by shifting from youth to old age in a constant parenthetical manner was a stroke of genius.The rise of young John Edgar Hoover from a mother-favored child, through the emotional conflicts this mother worship produced, through the sightings of incidents suggestive of early 'Bolshevik' interference/threat in this country that Hoover focused on in his usurping power as the head of the newly formed Federal Bureau of Investigation, provides a background from which we can observe the morphing of this obsessed man.  The act of staging press conferences around the Lindbergh case and the capture of the big criminals of the day were manipulated to give Hoover supreme power to investigate 'threatening people of interest' by wire taping, spying, etc. But all of this runs parallel to the personal story of Hoover's private sexual life.  From his living with his mother until her death, to his incompetent attempt to force himself on the woman who would be his secretary throughout his career, to his bonding with Clyde Tolson who he chose to be his assistant and never was far from his side, to his final hours when Tolson though suffering from the residuum of a stroke was the only person Hoover could trust as Richard Nixon planned his destruction.Each of the incidents that highlighted Hoover's long career as founder and head of the FBI is presented well, but it is the de-mystification of Hoover the vulnerable man beneath the tyrannical faade that makes this film so extremely powerful. That is due to the script and the direction, of course, but it is also due in large part to the brilliant portrayal of this enigmatic beast of a pathetic man by Leonardo DiCaprio: he remains credible throughout and moves through the aging process and intermittent flashbacks to his younger days with complete ease and credibility.  Likewise the performances of Judi Dench as his strange mother ('I'd rather my son be dead than be a daffodil' - her term for 'gay'), of Naomi Watts as his secretary who thwarts Hoover's initial awkward physical advances to become his lifelong supporter, and of Armie Hammer as Hoover's love interest Clyde Tolson acted with such a full range of emotion and subtlety that he is completely credible - these key roles are all of Oscar caliber as supporting roles.Eastwood's careful casting of actors for the roles of Charles Lindbergh (Josh Lucas), Eisenhower (Gunner Wright), Franklin Roosevelt (David A. Cooper), Harlan Fiske Stone (Ken Howard), Robert Kennedy (Jeffrey Donovan), Colonel Schwarzkopf (Dermot Mulroney), Bruno Hauptmann (Damon Herriman), Richard Nixon (Christopher Shyer), and Haldeman (Larkin Campbell) gives the audience the opportunity to catch glimpses of the people influenced by Hoover without stooping to caricatures.But in the end it is the slow dissection of the relationship between Hoover and Tolson that is the most powerful element of this film.  The audience is left with little doubt that these men were, in truth,  lovers without the expected obvious stereotypical activities and conversations.  It is an act of greatness on the parts of all involved, and for this reason probably more than any other aspect of this huge film, this biopic deserves to be in the lineup for Best Picture of the Year.  Grady Harp, November 11

reviewText: There is a lot to like about "J. Edgar." The actors to a person give stellar performances. Leonard DeCaprio as both the young and aging Hoover is totally believable and gives a performance for which he surely will be nominated for awards. Armie Hammer as Clyde Tolson, Mr. Hoover's longtime companion (?) is certainly easy on the eyes. It is easy to see why Hoover could have been attracted to him. Judi Dench as Hoover's mother just keeps on acting and can do anything. Naomi Watts as Hoover's Rosemary Woods is the totally devoted private secretary that every executive would kill for. Dustin Lance Black's ("Milk") screenplay and Clint Eastwood's directing (would that we all live to be 80 and look that good) are excellent. The understated photography is particularly effective. The details, the sets, the persons who swelled the crowd were flawless. But in the end the whole movie was not as good as the sum of its parts. And I cannot put my finger on just what was wrong. For one thing, the film certainly moved slowly. And as a friend of mine pointed out, there are certainly scenes in the movie that were pure fiction. On the other hand, the film is certainly worth seeing and is one that Mr. Eastwood has no reason to be ashamed of.

reviewText: I will be short on this film because it probably is one of the best by Clint Eastwood.First the actors. Its transformation from a semi-clandestine agency to a scientific, well trained and very effective and diligent institution. The film is clear how difficult it was to get laws passed and finances granted by Congress. Some of the arguments were opportunistic and some were logical, but they all had only one aim: to get what it needs to become the best. J. Edgar Hoover was in a way irritating in his way to serialize the action of the FBI for the nascent mass-media that the radio and the cinema were becoming. He was extremely disturbing in his umbilical ego-centeredness or ego-centricity. But that was him and the actor is able to render this cold, calculated and very tense character who had a problem with public elocution and had managed to overcome it with an extremely strict discipline.That leads to his action and his vision of the FBI. He was extremely authoritative and manipulative. He never took no for an answer and for him one no was always a disguised and hidden yes. He accumulated information on all the people he could one day depend on, politicians, congressmen and justices or judges, to blackmail them if necessary. He generally had his way and one of his major failures was with Martin Luther King that he could not blackmail into refusing the Nobel Peace Prize. The film is at times on the very verge of being embarrassing, though it only speaks of dead figures because it is dealing with rumors on Eleanor Roosevelt, Martin Luther King, John Fitzgerald Kennedy, Richard Nixon and a few others. I am not even sure some of the information is not frankly false.But Clint Eastwood is a patriot and he shows the patriotic side of the character with insistence and weight, to the point of reaching bigotry at times, for example on the subject of racism. He built the FBI in the fight against the anarchist and communist movement in the 20s and 30s, against the gangsters of the 20s and Prohibition, against the Germans in the 30s too, without specifying the political innuendo of the national reference in 1934 among Americans questioned by the FBI about someone who had a German accent. No nuance. Clint Eastwood gives his matter raw and uncooked at all.But Clint Eastwood reaches beyond these elements to capture the real personal and intimate dimension of his character. And here he is not using innuendo and allusions. J. Edgar Hoover's relation with his direct deputy is seen as a sentimental relation on the side of the deputy and an emotional relation on the side of J. Edgar Hoover himself. The tremendous condemnation of any gay orientation by his mother creates in him a tremendous struggle due to his attachment to his mother. The truth will come at the very end with a friendly even paternal kiss to his deputy on the night before dying. He will explain how he recruited him because he needed someone and he knew that young man needed a strong paternal figure that he accepted to be.Of course the revelation of the love of that young man for his boss is dramatized by Clint Eastwood, and maybe even too much because that was the intimate and private life of two men who did not reveal anything in public, far from it. But it is done with such delicacy, tenderness. J. Edgar Hoover appears in the film as having compensated the absence of a father figure and the presence of a strong authoritarian mother figure on his side, by playing that father figure with his direct deputy who needed such a father figure. The compensated lack of J. Edgar Hoover became the satisfaction of the need of his deputy. So much alike and yet so different.That personal touch in this film makes the film a lot more fascinating because it speaks of something that may happen to anyone: love is the only thing that survives in life and is stronger than even hatred as J. Edgar Hoover explains as he is climbing the stairs to his bedroom for the very last time in his life.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

reviewText: Clint Eastwood's "J. Edgar Hoover" gave me a better idea of why Harry Callahan emerged during the recent Repulican National Convention, and why he did the whole bit with an empty chair.  Clint Eastwood sees a sort of purity in monsters that is not in fact present.For anyone who watched this movie without knowing a whole lot about just who J. Edgar Hoover was should, before crying too many tears for him, check outOfficial and Confidential: The Secret Life of J. Edgar HooverandMasters of Deceit.  Leonardo DiCaprio does an excellent, and underrated, I think, of portraying Hoover's vulnerabilities (closet homosexual, an incestuous overdependent), the list could go on and on, but at no point does Eastwood reveal that behind this man of "high standards" and "excellence" was also a murderer.  The man who may have found some human understanding in Clyde Tolson, his second hand man (played by Armie Hammer with a touch too much of soft soap) also invented one of the most vicious, racist, and destructive programs ever to emerge from the U.S. Government: Cointelpro.  He had Fred Hampton, a Black Panther in his early twenties, murdered like a dog in his sleep.  He wanted to assassinate Martin Luther King with a passion, but there's no evidence that he had enough power to do it at that particular point in history.What we see on the screen is a young, ambitious, slightly neurotic young man who wants to make his mark on the world and who is absolutely obsessed with control.  We see an old man who was still living in the Cold War.  We see his "accomplishments", if you want to call them that: the creation of the FBI, fingerprinting, etc etc.  Was Eastwood also secretly sad that Hoover never had a chance to get involved in racial profiling?The performances from Naomi Watts and Judi Dench are phenomenal.  I didn't see any problem with the makeup, as some other viewers had.  I had a big problem, though, with having to look through the eyes of Clint Eastwood regarding this particular monster.  Even his destruction of Emma Goldman's lifeAnarchism and Other Essays,Living My Lifeis given a sympathetic treatment.Some parts are funny because you get to watch Hoover jump up and down in front of the mirror whining about how he can't dance with women.  The amusement factor only lasts so long, though, and I question where the heart of old Clint is these days.If Hoover had been raised in Nazi Germany, he would have been Rudolph Hess if not the man with the small mustache.  I recommend this film only if you like character studies of unpleasant (and that's an understatement) figures.
summary: Too Much Sympathy for the Devil

reviewText: A young J. Edgar (Leonardo Dicaprio) works in the Department of Justice.  He is an intelligent young man who excels at organizing data and seeing into what needs to be done to gather data to track radicals, communists and criminals.  Law enforcement at that time was archaic at best and databases on people did not exist or if they did they were only on a local basis.One evening the Attorney General of the US, several Senators, Federal Judges and prominent politicians' homes were bombed in 8 different locations at the same time.  J. Edgar is at the scene of his boss's home bombing shortly after it occurs collecting evidence. It leads to the arrest of communist radicals trying to subvert the American government.J. Edgar worked on a project to organize the library in Washington DC and he wanted to create the same type of data gathering and logging as he had helped use to set up the library.  He was among the first to push for fingerprinting and tracking of radicals and criminals.  The federal law enforcement agency at that time was weak and considered a joke.  They were not allowed to issue warrants, carry guns, arrest anyone or deport anyone.  At a very young age J. Edgar was appointed to be the head of the Bureau of Investigations and he basically set up the FBI and its investigative arms.  He believed in scientific investigative data and set up the famous FBI labs.He got what he wanted partially because he has gathered data files on presidents, congressmen, politicians and famous people.  He uses the dirt he has gathered to coerce those people to pass laws or to finance whatever he deems is necessary to move the FBI to his agenda...This is a very good storyline and follows some of the facts of history fairly well.  It is a tale of a driven paranoid man who trusts no one.  Most successful people are paranoid and he is no different.  He has his private secrets that finally begin to come out but everyone in power is terrified of his secret files.  I found it difficult to understand how the issues of J. Edgar's possible homosexual behavior became such a major part of this film. Unproven allegations seem to fit into Hollywood's eagerness to include such items into this film.  They wouldn't have had the courage to do this movie when he was alive!This movie is well acted by the entire cast.  I do think that one thing that hurt this movie's rating is that all of the actors are young and they wind up portraying the actual characters even up into their old age.  The old age special makeup is a bit overdone and you can't hardly help yourself but think that this is really a 30 year old person playing someone in their 60s and 70s.Despite that fact my wife and I enjoyed the movie and the acting.  The storyline is good but a bit dark in nature as J. Edgar was a cynical and paranoid man but that is part of what made him ideal for this job in America's troubled times.  He helped to make the FBI the leading criminal investigative organization in the world and helped to resolve some of major issues in those troubled times.
summary: A better movie than some give it credit for!

This man could walk into the office of some of the most powerful men in our governments history and exercise complete control of events in his favor. reviewText: First, I must start by saying that I'm not an uncoditional fan of either Clint Eastwood or Leonardo DiCaprio. I find many Eastwood films excessively solemn and on the service of somewhat melodramatic material (like the overrated Mystic River). As for DiCaprio, although his seriousness and commitment to acting has never seemed in doubt, he has seemed somewhat lightweight or miscast in many of his role.But this time, and despite being ignored by the Academy, Eastwood and DiCaprio, aided by a superb script by Dustin Lance Black, have stricken gold. DiCaprio has probably never had a role as demanding as this and Eastwood brings out the best in him.And the material perfectly suits Eastwood autumnal, melancholic tone this time, as we are talking about an American Epic, and the history of one of the most powerful men in the history of the United States. One of the most rewarding aspects of Eastwood's history films (as with Flags of Our Fathers), is that the director makes you take a fresh point of view. At this point in history, Hoover is equated in most of our minds with power mad, cross dressing, closeted bad guy, and then the movie reminds you of the man's instrumental role in building the FBI; yes, his tactics were nasty and he always took all the credit, but he helped bring crimefighting to a whole new level. The movie does a good balancing act of showing Hoover the Brilliant Man and Hoover the monster, if maybe at the end the portrayal might feel a little too sympathetic or apologetic. This would be more directed at Hoover the person, than at Hoover the politician, who is shown blackmailing several presidents and wiretapping Martin Luther King.When it comes to his personal life, the movie stirred quite a bit of controversy, as some people felt that the fact that Hoover was most likely a closeted homosexual could have been show more forcefully, and that it was just suggested; in fact the movie seemed to me quite clear on the subject.DiCaprio immerses completely in the role, and we finally can forget Leo the pretty boy, and watch the actor: awkard around women, smitten by a handsome new colleague, ferocious and bombastic speaking in public, shameless in playing hardball with people like RFK. It is an amazing performance and probably the best by an American actor in 2011. Equally fine are Arne Hammer, as Hoover's longtime companion, and Naomi Watts, as his lifetime secretary.It is impossible to come out of a biographical or historical picture with a comprehensive view of its subject, at best it's a starting point to delve deeper in the subjects it explores. In this, J. Edgar does an impressive job, and kudos to Eastwood and DiCaprio for embarking in such an ambitious venture.

reviewText: Throughout an illustrious directing career Clint Eastwood has delivered outstanding movies such as Unforgiven, Mystic River, and Million Dollar Baby, for which he has won five Academy Awards, for best Picture, Best Director, and including the Irving Thalberg Life Achievement Award. My personal favorite of all his directed movies is Gran Torino.The actors who have worked with him have been blessed with Oscar: Gene Hackman for Unforgiven, Tim Robbins and Sean Penn for Mystic River, Morgan Freeman and Hilary Swank for Million Dollar Baby.When I heard Clint Eastwood was doing a movie about Hoover, I admit I was somewhat excited, although it would be a challenging movie to do.I wondered would it deal with the relationship with the Kennedys, conspiracy theories, Hoover's alleged homosexuality, and alleged crossdressing, if it would deal with the entire career, if it would dare to show him in all his unpleasantness and darkness.If Hoover were alive today, I think he would be horrified at this movie. Undoubtedly, no such movie could have been made while he was alive.J Edgar deals with the entire span of J Edgar's career and makes brave choices in portraying the relationship between he and his No 2, Colson. The screenplay was written by same person who wrote the screen play for Milk.Leonardo DiCaprio making his first movie apart from Martin Scorsese in 12 years does an outstanding job in the title role, as does Arnie Hammer in the role of Colson. Naomi Watts plays Hoover's long time secretary to whom he proposes early in the movie, and Judi Dench plays his domineering and controlling mother.We see certain conflicts, and Hoover's use of Machivellian tactics in pursuing communists, upholding his position as head of the FBI through investigating the high ranking politicians who proved a threat. Whatever one thinks about Hoover one has to acknowledge some brilliance particuarly in organising, popularising the use of fingerprinting evidence, organising a national criminal database leveraging the Lindbergh tragedy to increase his own powers, and creating a highly respected investigative organisation.It was interesting to see how he was able to use propaganda to boost the reputation of the FBI. At one time the gangsters seemed to hold sway in the public consciousness as heroes, until the FBI's machine gun toting G men replaced them. We also see Hoover's vanity and narcissism in full display, and his racism particularly towards Martin Luther King.The Hoover story unfolds with Hover dictating his memoirs to a succession of agents. Why would he not use his secretary for this? It seems he wishes to tell his story to these people for vanity, and to promote himself as a legendary icon.In reality, Hoover was a temple of secrets, and probably the least likely person you could imagine would write his own memoirs. Although, he secretly tape recorded JFK, and MLK for exmaple, his relationship with Colson could possibly have ended his career if the true nature of the relationship became public. It's well known for example that Hoover did not allow women agents, nor did he hire African Americans. Yet, we have him dictating his memoirs at one point to an African American agent.One of the challenges with the story was the lack of a continuous protagonist, he mostly does battle with entities rather than individuals, such as communism and organised crime. By the 1960s apparently, he got soft on organised crime, while Bobby Kennedy got hard. Yet we have only two scenes in the movie with Bobby Kennedy.Another difficulty is the excessive use of makeup on several of the actors. With DiCaprio it's fine, but with Naomi Watts, and Arnie Hammer they wear bloodshot contact lenses which was over the top and unnecessary, and distracting. Old people do not necessarily have bloodshot eyes.I thought the performances by both DiCaprio and Hammer were deserving of Oscar recognition, though neither were nominated.While Clint Eastwood has probably brought me more enertainment than anyone as both an actor and director, I am not as staunch a supporter of this movie as the others in recent years such as Changeling, Gran Torino, and Invictus. Nevertheless I give it 4 stars because I think it was a very challenging movie to do well.I hope this was helpful.

reviewText: I was looking forward to seeing the movie J. EDGAR. I was never a fan of the man it was about, but with all the information brought out over the years about the secretive man who managed to create perhaps the most effective law enforcement organization ever I thought there should be a great story to be told here. There still is but this isn't the movie that does so.For those who don't know the name, J. Edgar Hoover was the creator of and the driving force behind the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) for decades. Not only was he the man responsible for putting the bureau together, he ran it when America was under attack by subversives, during the depression when criminals seemed more famous than those tracking them and later on when the FBI took on the Mafia at the behest of Attorney General Robert Kennedy.The film takes us through the various stages of Hoover's life from his early start at working for the Attorney General when the first outcry of radical attacks came. Still living at home Hoover was heavily influenced by his mother (played here by Judi Dench). It was her desire to see her son reinvigorate the Hoover name once again in Washington and he eventually did so.We watch as Hoover moves back and forth through time as he narrates passages of his memoirs to a subordinate taking us to those times when events actually happened. Along with these memories we get a chance to see Hoover for who he was as well, especially the man who witnessed so many politicians attempt to use the bureau for political reasons that he established a series if private files he kept on any and all people in power to use against them should they stand in his way. Had that been the main force behind the story here it would have been much more interesting.Instead writer Dustin Lance Black and director Clint Eastwood seem more interested in the seedier side of Hoover's life. In doing so the story of the man behind the FBI becomes a love story more than anything else. And that love story revolves around the tabloid fed stories about Hoover being gay and involved with his trusted friend Clyde Tolson (Armie Hammer). There is little doubt according to some that they were involved but why make that the focus especially when stating in so many press releases that it wasn't?The story that develops here does come through in the idea that Hoover became obsessed with his ideas that Communists were attempting to subvert the country that he loved; that more than anything portrays him as the patriot that he was, a man who loved his country above all else. But rather than show that yes, there were subversives who attempted to overthrow this country that were caught, it appears there were more civil rights violations going on that deserved more coverage. Granted Hoover was wrong on many of these occasions, but to display one side without the other seems disingenuous.We never see scenes of Hoover and Tolson in locked embrace or in bed together but much is made of their affection for one another. There is one brief heated kiss but that's all. Perhaps that was a gesture towards the fact that what went on behind closed doors was only known for certain to Hoover and Tolson themselves. But the longing for one another takes up more than half of the screen time seen here and for me made the picture more boring than anything.Leonardo DiCaprio does a fantastic job portraying Hoover throughout the various ages seen here. While some would credit the make up artists for much of that portrayal, more goes into it than that. How a man walks, how he talks, how he carries himself in various stages of life bring out the character being portrayed and DiCaprio displays that here.Hoover was an interesting man. His change from law defender to law breaker is interesting. His efforts to create the best crime fighting organization is interesting. His love life is not. I have yet to fathom the desire of Hollywood and their goal to dismantle each and every hero we have in our past. They seem determined to talk less about the accomplishments made by everyone from Thomas Jefferson to Hoover and more inclined to talk about the salacious details of their lives. Perhaps they've become influenced by the commercials that once ran for THE ENQUIRER that said "Enquiring minds want to know". I for one do not. I'm much more appreciative of movies that cover all bases and spend less time on dirt.
summary: SOME SECRETS SHOULD STAY THAT WAY

reviewText: A tale about J. Edgar Hoover (played by Leonardo DiCaprio) which takes the stance he was a repressed homosexual. Historians and people who knew Hoover vary in their opinions so you can believe what you wish but sometimes there seems to be an agenda involved rather than an attempt to seek out the truth. Hollywood wanted something controversial for a character that is probably unknown to the standard male moviegoers under 30 so I suspect that might be one of the reasons they went in this direction.But that said this is a good tale about the man which starts with him working in the Department of Justice when some anarchists were quite extreme and tried to kill off important politicians and government workers, including the boss of Hoover, Attorney General Alexander Mitchell. Yes, it's true that an anarchist by the name Luigi Galleani tried to mail a bomb to him that would detonate upon being opened. Fortunately for Mitchell the bomb was discovered and defused. Anyway, I felt that setting down this disturbing incident gave an interesting perspective as to why Hoover was so mistrusting of any groups that deviated from the norm. Some anarchists in those days were basically like the terrorists today and the Palmer Raids (basically the deportation of said anarchists and other suspicious left wing types) may have very well been justified back in that period. Just do a bit of Wiki research on anarchists to see all the people they tried to kill in America.Said incident also explains in his later years why he was unwilling to see Martin Luther King as somebody peacefully trying to change the world better socially but it could also be that outright racism towards African Americans was perfectly acceptable. That said, the movie doesn't have issue with showing his flaws in violating the privacy of others (not so much of a legal right back then as it is today) and collecting dirt on Presidents and other powerful people so as to maintain control and his job position. The outcome of the Lindbergh kidnapping was accurate and back then it was named "The Crime of the Century". Hoover is shown to dramatize or outright lie about the truth if it made him look good (evidence for this is unknown to me per some online research). Overall, I would say this movie did a commendable job in showing the good and bad of J. Edgar Hoover who seemed demonized in his later years as an opponent to the popular President Kennedy Administration.Judi Dench plays Hoover's firm yet understanding mother who supports him in his rise to power as well as when he encounters the occasional hiccup. Look for the potential dance scene with Ginger Rogers and the fallout thereafter. This film was directed by Clint Eastwood. The budget was $35M and so far it's made a bit over $70M at the Box Office. DiCaprio was nominated for Best Actor by the Golden Globes and the American Film Institute put this in the Top Ten films to see for 2011.CHARACTERS/DIALOGUE: B plus; STORY/PLOTTING: B to B plus; ACCURACY OF HOOVER HISTORICALLY: B plus to A minus; WHEN WATCHED: yesterday; OVERALL GRADE: B plus.

reviewText: Anybody who knows me at all probably knows that I'm a big Clint Eastwood fan - though I have never been and all-worshiping one. Clint's stumbled plenty of times in his long career, and he's quite capable of turning out a film that leaves me cold (see both "Changeling" and "Trouble With the Curve" among recent films that didn't do it for me). And though the story on this one was certainly interesting, I can't say I've been super-impressed with Leonardo DiCaprio up to this point. The reviews in general weren't so great, but many of the comments from reviewers and friends I trust have been better. And then again, I loved "Hereafter", which also got mixed responses. So...cautious optimism going in, at best.So I'm pleased to report that "J. Edgar", though it certainly isn't perfect and has a few significant problems, succeeded far beyond my expectations. If DiCaprio never gives another great performance in his career, he should be remembered for his thoughtful, enormously emotional and painful portrait of this rigid, more-tightly-wound-than-should-be-possible, permanently adolescent autocrat. The Hoover created by the actor, director, and screenwriter Dustin Lance Black is unquestionably a closeted gay (or bisexual) man, let's get that out of the way first; but he is the product of a conservative God-fearing mother, a society in which there's only one acceptable kind of sexuality and behavior, and he's ambitious and needs to be in power and control of everything, including himself. The film manages one of the most difficult feats imaginable - creating a thoroughly unpleasant and largely amoral character, and then proceeding to make him likable and sympathetic - something which will I'm sure be a turn-off for many viewers who either want a straight-arrow Hoover or a simple villain. This isn't anything like either, but rather a small, hypocritical and fearful man who can only find love in his work and an apparently sexless companionship with his closest lieutenant; someone who acts out of the pettiest of spites and ruins lives - because as a hollow shell of power surrounding a void of fear and self-doubt it's the only thing he can do to make a life for himself. Controlling and spying on others becomes his way to live the life he can't let himself have, so it's no wonder that spying on sex lives and an obsession with race (the rumors of Hoover's partially African origins are explored only slightly and rather subtly here) become defining characteristics.The film proceeds mostly in the form of flashbacks, as an aged Hoover recounts his triumphs to a series of stenographers in the 1960s, taking credit for much of the work on the Lindbergh kidnapping case, and the victories against gangsters in the 1930s. We see early on how a 24-year-old Hoover becomes obsessed with finding new techniques to defeat crime, using fingerprinting and forensics before they became de rigeur, and starting his lifelong crusade against Communism at the same time. One idea the film explores over and over is that the man always wanted to simplify things - always believed in easy answers, in a black and white yes/no world, and this of course becomes a great irony when we look at his complex, deceit-filled private life; and he also, from the first, was a man willing to take credit for others' ideas. Even when it came to dress, Hoover the fashion-plate got his sense of style from his assistant/companion Clyde Tolson (Armie Hammer, just as good as DiCaprio), and when he admires the fireplace in Attorney General Robert Kennedy's office, it's no surprise that we later see an identical model installed in his own.Much of the film is built on rhyming scenes like the Kennedy one, sometimes several minutes or an hour or more apart, sometimes built as abrupt transitions, such as an elevator ride taken by the elderly Hoover and Tolson that ends with the 30-year-younger pair getting off the same elevator. Far from being just cinematic flash (not really something Eastwood is known for), these serve to emphasize the lifelong metastasis of the man - 48 years in the same job, living with his mother until her death, keeping the same office for virtually his whole career. 48 years, and though the powerful man is old and withered, he is at the end in almost the same place he began, frozen by his own fears and secrets and emptiness. Three times we see him look out his window, past the Capital, down Pennsylvania Avenue, and we hear cheers - but they are not for him. These scenes reminded me of the way in which Sergio Leone told "Once Upon a Time in America", and in fact there's a moment early on in "J. Edgar" where Eastwood's music seems to quote Morricone's score for that film, just for a second. It could be a coincidence, but whether it is or not, both films at their hearts are films of regret and unrequited love over decades of a lifetime, and both are, at the end, almost unbearably sad.I do have some issues with the film; though they aren't major for me I suspect both might be bigger problems for others. One is the cinematography; it's by Eastwood's regular DP Tom Stern, and it's mostly in that muted washed out look that we also saw in "Million Dollar Baby" (where I thought it was pretty appropriate) and even moreso in "Letters From Iwo Jima". I suppose in a way it reflects the bleak, colorless world that Hoover lived in, emotionally, but it often just looked dull to me. I wondered at first if it was the poor projection when I saw it theatrically, but having seen the film now again on DVD, it remains an issue for me. The second area is the period of young Hoover's life; it would I think help strengthen the story, the character, if there was a little more exploration here; then again, one gets the sense that Hoover had little nostalgia beyond his powerful love for his mother (Judi Dench), and little interest in or patience for children (except when they could help his image, as a brief photo-op with Shirley Temple attests). His life was the FBI, and so perhaps it is appropriate that that's what we see of it, and even Tolson, and Hoover's career-long faithful secretary Helen Gandy (Naomi Watts - fine, though the role isn't as much as it perhaps could be) are often just sprockets in that mechanism.A lot of people obviously are disliking this; it's a very divisive film for both those who hate Hoover the autocrat (too sympathetic) and those who admire him but don't want to deal with his (possible) sexuality.  And there are always complaints about Eastwood's un-flashy style, and about DiCaprio.  And of course, being a film about real history, any liberties taken will be too many for a lot of folks. Too bad I say. What the filmmakers have crafted here is both a sad portrait of a fairly pathetic - if very powerful - man, and one of cinema's great stories of unrequited, repressed love.  Whether it is "real" or not seems beside the point to me; the emotional power of the film resides in what is on the screen, not on what we think we know about the real people who we're seeing in artistic reflection and imagination.

reviewText: There's no doubt that Leonardo DiCaprio gives a towering performance as J. EDGAR in Clint Eastwood's film of that name, nor that the other supporting performances are equally well-played by a fine cast. I never found the age make-up and prosthetics used to give DiCaprio a remarkable resemblance to the older Hoover a distraction, as others have claimed. His brisk, authoritative manner barking orders while riddled with a personality that covered a whole range of eccentricities, is nothing short of brilliant. All of the main facets of Hoover's life while in office stick pretty much to the truth in the script.But the film's basic flaw is that there's almost too much to tell about Hoover and not enough time to give any of the material more than a surface look. And the fact that the story is going back and forth in time holds up the momentum when it comes to the segments dealing with the Lindbergh kidnapping. What should have reached the peak of intensity in the story is muffled by the fact that the script spaces the event amid a period of other happenings, all of which take away a strong enough focus on "the trial of the Century."Eastwood's direction of the players is so strong that this flaw doesn't really matter in the end. He gets across a full illumination of the kind of man Hoover was, despite all the complexities stemming from his attachment to a dominating mother (Judi Dench) and made even more apparent by his singular attachment to his fellow co-worker at the FBI (Armie Hammer) as Clyde Tolson. Scenes between DiCaprio and Hammer reach a peak moment in their physical struggle as Hammer reacts violently to Hoover's admission of getting "serious" with Dorothy Lamour.Many personalities of the '30s and '40s are impersonated from time to time, the least convincing being the child actress chosen to represent Shirley Temple, who adored the F.B.I. Aside from blonde ringlets, she in no way resembles that child star in looks, speech or manner. Much closer are Ginger Rogers and Anita Colby. Nixon is played by an actor considerably more handsome than the original and Josh Lucas only makes an acceptable Charles Lindbergh.But whatever casting flaws there are, all of the main supporting roles are very capably entrusted to the right people. Naomi Watts does a fine job as Helen Gandy and Judi Dench is likewise admirable as Annie Hoover. In the end, though, it's a good film that might have been great with a tighter script.And certainly, DiCaprio can look forward to an Oscar nomination for Best Actor of 2011. Whether he wins or not, it's a role he put a lot of guts into and the payoff is there for all to see.
summary: Remarkable performance by DiCaprio maintains credibility throughout...

reviewText: "J. Edgar" is a biographical drama film starring Leonardo DiCaprio as Hoover.There is no doubt that there are aspects of Hoover's life and career that are highly concerning and controversial. However, this film focuses too heavily on the negative facets, and the lack of balance in this movie damages its credibility.I don't dispute that Hoover was at times unethical and egotistical but who really knew him? His mother, Clyde Tolson, and Helen Gandy were the qualified experts of Hoover, yet it doesn't appear that their superior knowledge of his demeanour, idiosyncrasies, life and career philosophy have been captured sufficiently for the purpose of accurately representing Hoover. All of these people are now deceased and without their input any interpretation of Hoover can only be considered as partially complete.Hoover does deserve some credit for the centralisation of laws and regulations by pushing for them to be federally binding, and it certainly makes sense for example that the deaths of federal officials fall within the FBI's jurisdiction, which was one of Hoover's later contributions. In the film Hoover was given some credit for the Federal Kidnapping Act following the kidnapping of Charles Lindbergh Jr. He is also given credit for embracing enhanced methodologies for crime scene investigation.The quality of acting is highly commendable and does to some extent offset what is an underrepresented narrative.Nicholas R.W. Henning - Australian Author

reviewText: If you are expecting ridicule, vilification, or even justification, this would be the wrong movie to watch on J. Edgar Hoover.Eastwood delivers a dark brooding, and rather objective look at one of the most controversial and polarizing figures in America. While the story itself may not be overly compelling, it does offer explanations behind some of the motivations that made up the man, John Edgar Hoover. The cinematography was a crucial element in creating and maintaining throughout a sense of secrecy, brooding, alienation, as well as distance.  The chronology is disparate and effective:  at times we see Hoover dictating his memoirs to an array of journalists and then we are taken back to the time in question, all the while framed in this overcast mood that fits the film and its subject matter perfectly.  As a matter of fact, the manner in which this was filmed constitutes, to me, the biggest indication of Eastwood's opinion one way or the other - Hoover was a dark man with some even darker secrets.J.Edgar's homosexuality as well as his proclivity for cross-dressing are only suggested and are handled with the utmost sensitivity.  There is one scene which strongly implies his helplessness with his desires to cross-dress that was simply quite touching.  And the relationship between Hoover and Tolson was beautifully written.  No, I did not come away feeling empathy/sympathy for Hoover at all; neither were any of my perceptions surrounding him challenged in the least.  I did leave the film however with surely a more heightened sense of his humanity.This could NOT have been accomplished however, were it not for the positively riveting performance by Di Caprio.  This guy can just ACT, okay? The other supporting players were equally excellent, most notably, Judi Dench who played his overbearing mother, Naomi Watts as his faithful secretary, Helen Gandy, and Armie Hammer, as Hoover's lifelong companion, Clyde Tolson.  Some of the movie's most compelling scenes involved these three and all three gave powerhouse supporting performances to match Di Caprio.I highly recommend as yet another excellent outing from a very good director.
